<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 154, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
0606/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 303, 904, 318]]<|/det|>
February/March 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 327, 904, 342]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 219, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 90]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 139, 566, 158]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 171, 245, 189]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 201, 390, 219]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2} + b x + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 220, 586, 255]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 276, 233, 293]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 297, 757, 336]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 351, 504, 388]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 415, 391, 433]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[253, 440, 539, 470]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\{2a + (n - 1)d\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 492, 339, 510]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = a r^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 515, 435, 580]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 616, 599, 635]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 649, 161, 666]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 677, 589, 728]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 772, 247, 789]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 797, 599, 833]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 833, 599, 853]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 860, 561, 890]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 76, 638, 100]]<|/det|>
Find the exact solutions of the equation \(3\big(\ln 5x\big)^2 +2\ln 5x - 1 = 0.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 97]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 82, 910, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 415, 920, 452]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y = a\sin bx + c\) where \(x\) is in radians and \(-2\pi \leqslant x \leqslant 2\pi\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are positive constants. Find the value of each of \(a, b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 433, 920, 452]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 843, 92]]<|/det|>
The line \(AB\) is such that the points \(A\) and \(B\) have coordinates \((- 4, 6)\) and \((2, 14)\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 910, 122]]<|/det|>
The point \(C\), with coordinates \((7, a)\) lies on the perpendicular bisector of \(AB\). Find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 658, 144, 677]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 658, 920, 694]]<|/det|>
Given that the point \(D\) also lies on the perpendicular bisector of \(AB\), find the coordinates of \(D\) such that the line \(AB\) bisects the line \(CD\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 675, 920, 694]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 96, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 144, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 76, 920, 101]]<|/det|>
Show that \(2x^{2} + 5x - 3\) can be written in the form \(a\big(x + b\big)^{2} + c\) , where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 95, 920, 113]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 301, 146, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 300, 813, 323]]<|/det|>
Hence write down the coordinates of the stationary point on the curve with equation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 317, 292, 336]]<|/det|>
\(y = 2x^{2} + 5x - 3.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 317, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 456, 143, 475]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 453, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
On the axes below, sketch the graph of \(y = \left|2x^{2} + 5x - 3\right|\), stating the coordinates of the intercepts with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 472, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 532, 875, 828]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 844, 146, 863]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 841, 920, 880]]<|/det|>
Write down the value of \(k\) for which the equation \(\left|2x^{2} + 5x - 3\right| = k\) has exactly 3 distinct solutions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 861, 920, 880]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 623, 92]]<|/det|>
In this question all lengths are in kilometres and time is in hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 92, 920, 160]]<|/det|>
Boat \(A\) sails, with constant velocity, from a point \(O\) with position vector \(\binom{0}{0}\). After 3 hours \(A\) is at the point with position vector \(\binom{- 12}{9}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 143, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 160, 504, 183]]<|/det|>
Find the position vector, \(\overrightarrow{OP}\), of \(A\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 181]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 280, 920, 343]]<|/det|>
At the same time as \(A\) sails from \(O\), boat \(B\) sails from a point with position vector \(\binom{12}{6}\), with constant velocity \(\binom{- 5}{8}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 346, 143, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 344, 504, 366]]<|/det|>
Find the position vector, \(\overrightarrow{OQ}\), of \(B\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 345, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 428, 144, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 422, 520, 448]]<|/det|>
Show that at time \(t\) \(\left|\overrightarrow{PQ}\right|^{2} = 26t^{2} + 36t + 180.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 428, 920, 447]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 717, 146, 736]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 715, 472, 736]]<|/det|>
Hence show that \(A\) and \(B\) do not collide.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 715, 920, 734]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 653, 89]]<|/det|>
A geometric progression has first term 10 and sum to infinity 6.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 181, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 101, 529, 120]]<|/det|>
Find the common ratio of this progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 101, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 308, 181, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 308, 923, 327]]<|/det|>
Hence find the sum of the first 7 terms, giving your answer correct to 2 decimal places. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 801, 96]]<|/det|>
The first three terms of an arithmetic progression are \(\log_{x}3\), \(\log_{x}(3^{2})\), \(\log_{x}(3^{3})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 106, 180, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 104, 571, 125]]<|/det|>
Find the common difference of this progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 237, 181, 255]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 234, 920, 255]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(n\) and \(\log_{x}3\), the sum to \(n\) terms of this progression. Simplify your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 252, 920, 271]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 484, 180, 503]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 483, 692, 504]]<|/det|>
Given that the sum to \(n\) terms is \(3081 \log_{x}3\), find the value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 483, 920, 503]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 717, 180, 736]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 715, 801, 736]]<|/det|>
Hence, given that the sum to \(n\) terms is also equal to 1027, find the value of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 715, 920, 734]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 583, 91]]<|/det|>
## DO NOT USE A CALCULATOR IN THIS QUESTION

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 473, 106]]<|/det|>
In this question all lengths are in centimetres.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 114, 856, 304]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 322, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a trapezium \(ABCD\)E such that \(AB\) is parallel to \(EC\) and \(ABCD\) is a rectangle. It is given that \(BC = \sqrt{17} +1\), \(ED = \sqrt{17} -1\) and \(DC = \sqrt{17} +4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 370, 146, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 370, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the trapezium, giving your answer in the form \(a + b\sqrt{17}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 388, 920, 406]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 675, 146, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the trapezium, giving your answer in the form \(c + d\sqrt{17}\), where \(c\) and \(d\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 688, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 808, 107]]<|/det|>
Find \(\tan AED\), giving your answer in the form \(\frac{e + f\sqrt{17}}{8}\), where \(e\) and \(f\) are integers. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 285, 144, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 276, 479, 307]]<|/det|>
Hence show that \(\sec^2 AED = \frac{81 + 9\sqrt{17}}{32}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 285, 920, 304]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 143, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 180, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 484, 92]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\sin x \tan x + \cos x = \sec x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 437, 180, 456]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 428, 923, 459]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(\sin \frac{\theta}{2}\tan \frac{\theta}{2} +\cos \frac{\theta}{2} = 4\) for \(0\leqslant \theta \leqslant 4\pi\), where \(\theta\) is in radians. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 603, 96]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 2x^{3} - 3x^{2} - x + 1\) has a factor \(2x - 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 688, 127]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) in the form \((2x - 1)\mathrm{q}(x)\), where \(\mathrm{q}(x)\) is a quadratic factor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 274, 803, 533]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 545, 920, 588]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y = \frac{1}{x}\) for \(x > 0\), and the graph of \(y = - 2x^{2} + 3x + 1\). The curves intersect at the points \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 599, 144, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 599, 724, 618]]<|/det|>
Using your answer to **part (a)**, find the exact \(x\)-coordinate of \(A\) and of \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 599, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 473, 88]]<|/det|>
Find the exact area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 875, 665, 894]]<|/det|>
Question 10 is printed on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 97, 104, 115]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 79, 517, 120]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \frac{\left(2x^{2} + 10\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}}{x - 1}\) for \(x > 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 135, 144, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 133, 920, 177]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) can be written in the form \(\frac{\left(2x^{2} + 10\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}}{\left(x - 1\right)^{2}} (Ax^{2} + Bx + C)\), where \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\) are integers. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 146, 517]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 498, 920, 534]]<|/det|>
Show that, for \(x > 1\), the curve has exactly one stationary point. Find the value of \(x\) at this stationary point. [4]
